comment.narrative: 1. As to the latest data available at The Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project website, Uzbekistan currently ranked 12,02 in Control of Corruption Index that is significant progress compared to 8,65 in 2015, and to 10 in 2017. 3. Currently the number of digital services by government agencies using frameworks that leverage digital technologies and big data for delivery of public services increased significantly. Besides my.gov.uz, the citizenry may apply for monitoring delivery of services to pm.gov.uz portal, and get digitalized public services on websites of several public institutions, including Ministry of Finance, General Prosecutors’ office, State Committee on Geology, Ministry of Internal Affairs, and others. One of the most popular methods of Public engagement using digital technologies in 2018 became creating special platform on popular social media networks: Republican commission on combatting corruption and General Prosecutor’s Office triggered Anticorruptionuz_bot platform for engaging publicity in discussing of corruption issues and developing corruption prevention measures. 5. The rise is demonstrated in capacity building of public servants and law enforcement officials in anticorruption domain. Together with Republican Commission on combatting Corruption, international community in Uzbekistan actively engaged in this direction, including UNDP, UNODC, OSCE and GIZ. Cumulatively around 15 different training sessions were conducted for Government people, each covering from 25 to 100 participants. Only UNDP PCEAT Project conducted capacity building training and study tour, covering more than 225 public institutions employees, including 70 women, in 2018. __ Besides above, there are results related to other Project targets that are planned for next years: Ministry of Justice of Uzbekistan (MoJ) conducted legal expertize of 1850 normative legal acts in 2018 with compulsory anticorruption screening, and only 68,6% were approved with or without comments, others returned to initiators due to significant improvement needs. MoJ itself in 2018 initiated 230 normative legal acts streamlining governance operations in different public domains, including 29 draft Laws. In 2018, the Public Services (PSs) Centers under MoJ (PS One Stop Shops) increased the number of public services types rendered through Centers from 37 to 103. 16 types of PSs were streamlined by specific regalement approved by Government. The number of Public Services rendered increased twenty times - from 120K in 2017 to 4600K in 2018. The number of complaints from citizenry received by MoJ regarding Public Services quality decreased from 12K to 6K that witnesses increase in responsiveness and quality of PSs delivery. 2018 showed definite rise of mass media activity in reporting corruption cases and corrupted practices. As the majority of reports are generally reposting from the mass media leaders, we may orient to analysis of materials of one the most popular media site kun.uz, that reported throughout a year more than 60 corruption cases associated with bribery and abuse of power. Notably that it reported 10 cases during the first half of the year and around 50 cases in the second half that points to gradual rise of determination in media approach to the issue. To focus more on details of PCEAT activity, in 2018, the Project focused on triggering and enhancing its visibility and role in supporting anticorruption system building in country. Among feasible achievements we may indicate contracting 16 National Experts for developing policy and analytical support in anticorruption domain, and one International Consultant for OECD Monitoring Mission, organization of Study Tour of the High Level Officials Delegation consisting of 12 top managers of public institutions headed by the Minister of Justice and Deputy General Prosecutor of Uzbekistan to Singapore and Korea to explore the experience of Anticorruption Agencies of Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Indonesia, Bhutan and Republic of Korea and opportunities to establish working relations with these agencies. Another tangible technic aid delivered by the Project was supply of 1000 pieces of the modern computing equipment (monoblocks) to General Prosecutor’s Offices division named Compulsory Enforcement Bureau with the newest software that will be used for billing operations, timely and effective responsiveness and monitoring of public services. Besides, the Project was principal organizer of The International Conference dedicated to International Anticorruption Day December 9, conducted in Tashkent, and Weekly Anticorruption Media Marathon arranged jointly by Uzbekistan Public Anticorruption institutions and international community in country, conducting six major propaganda events in total throughout the week. The Project also supports the 4-th round of monitoring of Istanbul Anti-Corruption Action Plan Implementation in Uzbekistan, conducted by special OECD Monitoring Team. The Project continues to be of high relevance as plays important role in providing policy and program support to the Governmental Anticorruption institutions and in creating collaboration environment and joint actions platform within international community together with OSCE, UNODC, OECD, the number of think tanks, CSO and academia circles. The Project has initiated resource mobilization operations already making application for fund raising to several international donors, like UNDP Seoul Policy Center and United Kingdom Embassy in Tashkent.

1. As to the latest data available at The Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project website, Uzbekistan currently ranked 12,50 in Control of Corruption Index that is significant progress compared to 12,02 in previous year and exceeds target for 2019.
2. Ministry of Justice of Uzbekistan (MoJ) conducted legal expertize of 2120 normative legal acts in 2019 with compulsory anticorruption screening and 2086 legal acts are adopted, and only 90% were approved with or without comments, others returned to initiators due to significant improvement needs. The declining number of draft legal acts that were rejected for adoption demonstrates improvement in quality of rulemaking and drafting. Target was achieved for 132%. The number of draft legal acts returned in 2019 for revisioning is 203 (725 in 2018, 992 in 2017), which is 10% from total number of legal acts submitted for legal expertize (28% in 2018, 31% in 2017).
3. a) my.gov.uz has been become the main government electronic tool that provides access to 180 public services, while 93 services are provided through Public Service Centers only physically. Moreover, almost all public institutions that has websites have special pages operating for rendering relevant public services online. E-auksion, E-Harid and other governmental portals were launched for providing services to business. b) Regulation.gov.uz has been extensively used by government agencies for public consultations. Government's e-petitions platform (meningfikrim.uz) is operating for citizens to allege their concerns and statements. Numerous other e-participation tools are being utilized by government agencies (jamoatchilik.uz, meningovozim.tashkent.uz) for solving specific tasks. c) Data.gov.uz, stat.uz and openbudget.uz are used by government agencies and citizens as source of open data. d) Primary identification sources for delivering public services are (if in-person) internal passport and (if online) several digital identification platforms (One ID, ID.uz, State Tax Agency Digital Identity System, UNICON's Digital Identity System). New national ID system will be operationalised by 2021. National Agency of Project Management is considering the implementation of the single identification interface for users based on the ONE ID digital platform. UNDP is supporting agency in identifying the feasibility of using the biometric data for identifying user. f) Public procurement operations are regulated through several e-service tools like harid.uz, goszakupka.uz, uzex.uz (stock exchange). December 5, 2019, the new Presidential Decree was released to streamline public procurements for strategic state owned enterprises that established special web-portal for huge amount procurements and ensuring transparency and competitiveness. Another critical public service covered in 2019 was Public e-service on enrollment to public kindergartens.
4. Local mass media and information sources continued to report numerous corrupted practice cases detected and investigated by law enforcement throughout a year that raised huge public interest, engagement, discussion and in some cases criticism. While informal information sources like social media championed the criticism, formal mass media were also involved very much in reporting corruption like such web-media sources as kun.uz, podrobno.uz, gazeta.uz, uz.sputniknews.ru (operating from Russia) and others. The bigger public discussion was triggered by the series of publications related to criminal charges against the number of top public officials, including former Chief of Intelligence and General Prosecutor of the country. Several publications covered the arrest of judges, local governance (municipality) heads, police officials. This lead to that the General Prosecutor’s Office decided to open its data by itself and the first time it conducted press-conference in the Agency for Information and Mass Communications of Uzbekistan in June 2019, fully devoted to discussion of corruption status and anticorruption in the country. The last wave of mass media reports on corruption was launched after the latest meeting of the Republican Interagency Commission on combatting corruption hold in late December 2019, when the pervasive state of corruption in Healthcare Industry was revealed by the Commission and the huge amount of damage detected by law enforcement was announced by Commission Head – newly appointed General Prosecutor.
5. Totally twelve capacity building and educational events have been organized by PCEAT project in 2019, with the participation of 960 people, including 420 women, 587 representatives of state agencies and 93 foreign experts, including 40 women. These events promoted a zero-tolerance towards corruption in society and openly discussed corruption-related issues, with the inclusion of various stakeholders. 190 participants and government officials were trained in 2 training workshops, including 45 women: 1) Workshop on implementing the recommendations from the 4th Round of Monitoring of Uzbekistan under the OECD ACN/Istanbul Action Plan, and 2) Training on ‘Anti-Corruption in the Context of the 2030 Agenda’. As a result of the training, participants gained knowledge/skills in a range of topics on anti-corruption, that are in line with the government’s development and anti-corruption priorities. Three study tours were organised, where 38 government officials learned best practices from Norway, Denmark, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and OECD (France). The study tours enhanced the knowledge of government officials on how countries with low levels of corruption were able to promote transparency, accountability, efficiency, integrity and anti-corruption.

1. As to the latest data available at The Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project website, Uzbekistan currently ranked 14,42 in Control of Corruption Index that is significant progress compared to 12,98 in previous year and exceeds target for 2020.
2. The Ministry of Justice of Uzbekistan (MoJ) conducted legal expertise of 2272 normative legal acts in Y2020 out of 2476 received, with compulsory anticorruption screening. 1539 legal acts are adopted (68%) with or without comments, others returned to initiators due to improvement needs. The declining number of draft legal acts that were rejected for adoption demonstrates improvement in quality of rulemaking and drafting: the number of draft legal acts returned without legal expertise due to inconsistency with quality requirements in Y2020 is 204 (203 in 2019, 725 in 2018, 992 in 2017), which is 8 % from total number of legal acts received for legal expertise (10% in 2019, 28% in 2018, 31% in 2017). Target has been achieved for 133%.
3. Due to pandemic restrictions, provision of public services through electronic channels was the focus of the government in this direction. a) my.gov.uz has been still the main government electronic tool that provides access to 213 public services as at the 2020 (180 in 2019), while around 150 services are provided through Public Service Centers only physically, out of total 700 public services. In 2020, totally 3,5 mln applications for public services have been processed electronically. E-auksion, E-Harid were among governmental portals the most popular for business entities to get access to public procurement. b) Regulation.gov.uz has been extensively used by government agencies for public consultations. Government's e-petitions platform (meningfikrim.uz) is operating for citizens to allege their concerns and statements. Numerous other e-participation tools are being utilized by government agencies (jamoatchilik.uz, meningovozim.tashkent.uz) for solving specific tasks. c) Data.gov.uz, stat.uz and openbudget.uz are used by government agencies and citizens as source of open data. d) Primary identification sources for delivering public services are (if in-person) internal passport and (if online) several digital identification platforms (One ID, ID.uz, State Tax Agency Digital Identity System, UNICON's Digital Identity System). New national ID system will be operationalised by 2021. e) The most popular (critical) public services have been provided in education (kindergartens), customs, health and tax industries. However, the majority of them relates to provision of data and information to customer, while for receiving the complete service the customer needs still physically visit Public Services Centers, Customs and Tax Authorities.
4. The media are becoming a key element of an effective anti-corruption and public oversight system. Several television channels and web resources have become the most popular among the population precisely due to publications on corruption, both at the national and local levels. Anti-corruption activists are gaining even more popularity on social networks and messengers. For instance, the statistics on Integrity (Anticorruption) Awards conducted by Anticorruption Agency jointly with international organizations, including UNDP, shows the growth in the number and relevance of the publications about corruption. UNDP supported the holding of the Integrity Award in nominations related to media anticorruption activities, such as “The Best Journalistic Anticorruption Investigation”, “The Most Active Media in Anticorruption Advocacy”, and “For Anticorruption Activeness in Social Networks (bloggers, groups, channels, etc.). And 49 journalistic investigation works have been accepted for the nomination the Best Journalistic Investigation only. Publications of web-resources Kun.uz, Gazeta.uz, social channels davletov.uz, bakiroo, anticorruption groups in Facebook, not mentioning the formally blocked web-sites, have impacted government’s policy and formed a trend to immediate response and relevant reaction by the government.
5. Despite challenges and restrictions associated with pandemic, PCEAT project managed to host 16 anticorruption education and outreach events in 2020, mostly online, with the participation of around 800 people, including 320 women, 60% of them are representatives of state agencies, with involvement of 20 foreign experts, 10 of them are women. These events (webinars, seminars, round tables, conferences, forums) promoted a knowledge, skills, information sharing in anticorruption among public servicemen, as well as zero-tolerance towards corruption in society and openly discussed corruption-related issues, with the inclusion of various stakeholders. 20 employees of the Ministry of Justice, including 5 women, and 20 employees of the General Prosecutor’s Office have been specifically trained for ISO 37001:2016 “Anti-bribery management system” by SGS Company with certifying their level; 2) 290 government officials, including around 40 women, were trained in 12 training seminars conducted by KPMG Auditing Company with respect to implementation of anticorruption compliance system in public agencies, auditing for compliance and managing conflict of interest in public service. As a result, participants gained knowledge/skills in a range of topics on anti-corruption that are in line with the government’s development and anti-corruption priorities.
